title: 110_s656
content: The Act may be cited as the "Liberian Refugee Immigration Fairness Act of 2007" and includes provisions for the adjustment of status. The "Liberian Refugee Immigration Fairness Act of 2007" allows for the adjustment of status for eligible aliens to obtain permanent residence by April 1, 2009, without certain grounds for inadmissibility applying. The "Liberian Refugee Immigration Fairness Act of 2007" allows eligible aliens to adjust their status for permanent residence by April 1, 2009, with certain grounds for inadmissibility not applying. An alien is ineligible for adjustment of status if convicted of an aggravated felony or two crimes involving moral turpitude. States under the Immigration and Nationality Act may apply for adjustment of status without needing a separate motion if qualified. The Secretary of Homeland Security will cancel the order if the application is granted, but will uphold the order if the application is denied. The final decision to deny the application for adjustment of status will be effective and enforceable. Aliens eligible for adjustment of status must be nationals of Liberia and have been continuously present in the United States from January 1, 2007, through the date of application. This also applies to their spouses, children, or unmarried sons and daughters. For the purposes of establishing continuous physical presence, an alien is not considered to have failed by being absent for up to 180 days. The Secretary of Homeland Security can provide a stay of removal for aliens subject to deportation or removal orders. The Secretary of Homeland Security may authorize an alien in exclusion, deportation, or removal proceedings to work in the United States while their adjustment of status application is pending. The Secretary of Homeland Security may authorize employment for aliens with pending adjustment of status applications exceeding 180 days. Upon approval, a record of permanent residence is established. Applicants have the right to administrative review. The Secretary of Homeland Security may authorize employment for aliens with pending adjustment of status applications exceeding 180 days. A determination by the Secretary regarding alien status adjustment under this section is final and not subject to judicial review. If an alien is granted lawful permanent residence status, the Secretary of State is not required to reduce the number of immigrant visas available. The Immigration and Nationality Act provisions apply, with exceptions as provided in the Act. The definitions in the Immigration and Nationality Act apply to this section. This Act does not affect the Secretary of Homeland Security's powers in enforcing immigration laws. Eligibility for permanent residence status does not prevent an alien from seeking other eligible statuses under the law.
